Boston.com
10

Second rape reported near Harvard campus area

The rape happened sometime after 11 p.m. Tuesday in the area of Oxford and Kirkland streets, an area near the university science center, police said. (Globe, 3:09 p.m.)
  • 8/11 Woman raped in Harvard Yard

Olympic track star Demps to sign with Patriots

Olympic silver medalist Jeff Demps, who played running back at the University of Florida, will sign with the Patriots. (Globe, 1:14 p.m.)

BC Athletic Director DeFilippo retiring

BC Athletic Director Gene DeFilippo retires
Athletic Director Gene DeFilippo, who oversaw Boston College's move from the Big East to the Atlantic Coast Conference, said today he plans to retire. (AP, 3:15 p.m.)
  • Discuss  |  4/11/10 DeFilippo is a man for all seasons
  • 4/11/10 DeFilippo apologizes for ACC expansion remarks
  • 1/7/09 BC football coach fired | Basketball coach departs

Kraft Group seeks to expand Patriot Place

Robert Kraft's firm wants to expand its Patriot Place development with hundreds of housing units, several restaurants, and a hotel. (Globe, 4 p.m.)
  • 4/29 Trader Joe’s at Patriot Place gets alcohol OK

Romney nixes Obama bid for tax returns

President Obama's campaign offered to stop criticizing Mitt Romney over tax returns if he released five years, but the Romney camp rejected that deal. (AP, 2:31 p.m.)
  • Fake followers newest ploy, accusation in politics
  • Romney, Ryan to hold town hall meeting in N.H.

Health & Wellness

Affordable ways to get fit at home

According to the authors of Freakonomics, people who purchase gym memberships overestimate how often they will go by 70 percent. As a result, more than $500 of the average annual cost of memberships is simply lining the pockets of gym owners.

2 US troops killed by Afghan officer

A newly recruited Afghan village policeman fired on his American allies today, killing two US service members minutes after they handed him his official weapon in an inauguration ceremony.

The Big Picture

Cleanup begins after massive flooding in Manila

Relentless rains submerged at least a third to one half of the sprawling Philippine capital of Manila. At least 60 have died, most from drowning.
